repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), District Council 1707 Records
did.abstract: The American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), District Council 1707 Records document the administrative functions of Local 1707/DC 1707 (formerly the Community and Social Agency Employees Union). The Council's jurisdiction covers many categories of employees in private-sector social service agencies. Much of the material in the collection relates to the Council's dealings with agencies where Council members are employed (e.g. bargaining files, contracts, grievance files); the collection also contains Executive Board and Delegate Assembly meeting files; general administrative files for DC 1707, and its locals, committees, and chapters; records of some officers and staff; publications and publicity files; general subject files; as well as photographs, websites, and other media formats.
did.physloc: Materials stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact special.collections@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by AFSCME District Council 1707, under an agreement signed by Executive Director Raglan George, Jr., in December 2008. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2009.005, 2009.012, 2010.045, and NPA.2009.012.

Websites were initially selected by curators and captured through the use of The California Digital Library's Web Archiving Service in 2007 as part of the abor Unions and Organizations (U.S.) Web Archive. In 2015, these websites were migrated to Archive-It. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), District Council 1707 Records document the administrative functions of Local 1707/DC 1707, formerly known as the Community and Social Agency Employees Union (CSAE). Much of the material relates to the various agencies where Council members are employed; the collection also contains Executive Board and Delegate Assembly meeting files; general administrative files for DC 1707, and its locals, committees, and chapters; records of some officers and staff; publications and publicity files; and general subject files; as well as photographs and other media formats.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is arranged chronologically; Series II though VI are arranged alphabetically; Series VII and VIII are unprocessed. This collection is organized into nine series:
Series II: General Administrative and Locals Files, 1950-2006
Series IV: Officers and Staff-Administrative Files, 1962-2004

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; AFSCME, District Council 1707 Records; WAG 298; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

To cite the archived website in this collection: Identification of item, date; AFSCME, District Council 1707 Records; WAG 298; Wayback URL; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: District Council 1707 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) is the only council within AFSCME that is chartered exclusively to represent private, nonprofit employees. It currently represents about 25,000 workers throughout the New York City area (and New York State), including those within private sector fundraising and advocacy agencies, case work and group work agencies, teaching and related organizations, child care centers, home care services, and Head Start programs. In addition to advocating for better wages, benefits and conditions for employees within these various workplaces, the Council has worked to improve and expand social services in a number of areas. Many Council members work in government-funded private agencies and centers, and, through its Legislative Committee and other advocacy efforts, it has strenuously opposed city and state budget cuts. DC 1707 has also been a strong advocate for children's welfare since it first began organizing (subsidized) day-care centers in the late 1960s.

The Council began in 1932 as the Association of Federation Workers, a staff association within the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Over the ensuing decades, the association had several names and affiliations, including the Community and Social Agency Employees (CSAE), Local 1707. Local 1707 joined the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), District Council 37 in 1955, following the merger of the AFL and the CIO.

Local 1707 outgrew its single local structure by the early 1970s, as a result of growth in membership and its presence in increasingly diverse agencies. A membership referendum approved the establishment of District Council 1707 within AFSCME in December 1973 -- the culmination of a process which took several months. The first DC 1707 officers were nominated and elected in April 1974.

As of 2010, the Council consists of: Local 95 Head Start Employees, Local 107 National Membership and Fund Raising Employees, Local 205 Day Care Employees, Local 215 Social Service Employees, Local 253 Education Employees, Local 389 Home Care Employees, Local 1881 Association of Professional Personnel (Development Corporation for the State of Israel Bonds), and a Retirees Chapter.

DC 1707 also has various committees including the Political Action Committee, the Latino Committee, the Women's Committee, and the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists (CBTU) Committee. The union has been active throughout its history in advocating for civil rights and has encouraged the political involvement of its membership.

Among the Executive Directors of Local 1707 were Hilda Siff, Shirley Kera, and Benjamin Bially (1963-1968). Executive Director Richard Morton (1970-1984) oversaw the Local's restructuring into a district council. He was followed by Robert McEnroe (1985-1994) and Josephine LeBeau (1994-2002). Raglan George, Jr. became Executive Director of DC 1707 in 2002, after serving the Council in a number of capacities, including Director of Local 95 and Local 205.
In 2019, the DC 1707 merged with DC 37.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
relatedmaterial.p: AFSCME, District Council 37 Printed Ephemera Collection (PE 020)

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by AFSCME, District Council 1707, were transferred to New York University in 2008 by AFSCME, District Council 1707. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Archives. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Photographs separated from this collection during processing were established as a separate collection, the AFSCME, District Council 1707 Photographs (PHOTOS 270). In 2014, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the AFSCME, District Council 1707 Records (WAG 298).
In 2014, the archived websites were added as Series IX. Additional websites and administrative information was added to the finding aid in 2021.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to some audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact special.collections@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

appraisal.head: Take Down Policy
appraisal.p: Archived websites are made accessible for purposes of education and research. NYU Libraries have given attribution to rights holders when possible; however, due to the nature of archival collections, we are not always able to identify this information.
If you hold the rights to materials in our archived websites that are unattributed, please let us know so that we may maintain accurate information about these materials.

If you are a rights holder and are concerned that you have found material on this website for which you have not granted permission (or is not covered by a copyright exception under US copyright laws), you may request the removal of the material from our site by submitting a notice, with the elements described below, to the special.collections@nyu.edu.

Please include the following in your notice: Identification of the material that you believe to be infringing and information sufficient to permit us to locate the material; your contact information, such as an address, telephone number, and email address; a statement that you are the owner, or authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed and that you have a good-faith belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; a statement that the information in the notification is accurate and made under penalty of perjury; and your physical or electronic signature. Upon receiving a notice that includes the details listed above, we will remove the allegedly infringing material from public view while we assess the issues identified in your notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series includes material relating to meetings of Local 1707/DC 1707's Executive Board and Delegate Assembly. Executive Board meetings files include reports, activity reports from various officers, staff, and locals, financial records, event flyers, memoranda, constitutions, notes of various board members, schedules, and correspondence. Meetings files often contain minutes for the previous board meeting, and sometimes drafts or copies of minutes for the current meeting. Early Executive Board meetings files (1960s-1970s) are primarily minutes and drafts of minutes with a small amount of supporting documents (agendas, membership reports, attendance sheets). Up to 1973 the Executive Board files usually include material from meetings of the Joint City Council, apparently an early form of the Delegate Assembly.

Early Delegate Assembly meetings files (1981-1986) consist mostly of minutes and drafts of minutes. Meetings files include agendas, activity reports from various officers, staff and locals, drafts and copies of minutes, (including those of previous meetings), financial statements, event flyers, and attendance sheets.This series contains material pertaining to the administrative functions of Local 1707/DC 1707, its departments, locals, committees and chapters. General administrative material includes correspondence and memoranda, financial records and reports, and items that document Coucil elections, Executive Board, organizing, staff meetings, committees, and other areas. Locals and Retirees Chapter files contain similar material, as well as some trustee board and other meetings files, and records of funds for various locals. General Administrative files are arranged alphabetically by subject; locals follow, arranged by local number. Retirees Chapter material follows locals. DC 1707 locals are: Local 95 Head Start Employees, Local 107 National Membership and Fund Raising Employees, Local 205 Day Care Employees, Local 215 Social Service Employees, Local 253 Education Employees, Local 389 Home Care Employees, Local 1881 Association of Professional Personnel (Development Corporation for Israel).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material pertaining to the administrative functions of Local 1707/DC 1707, its departments, locals, committees and chapters. General administrative material includes correspondence and memoranda, financial records and reports, and items that document Coucil elections, Executive Board, organizing, staff meetings, committees, and other areas. Locals and Retirees Chapter files contain similar material, as well as some trustee board and other meetings files, and records of funds for various locals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Agency files document Local 1707/DC 1707's relationships with its members' workplaces. Bargaining material includes contracts, agreements and other signed documents, negotiation material, correspondence and memoranda, and notes relating to the collective bargaining process. Grievance files document individual and group grievances against employers. Personnel files generally contain information about workplace staff, hiring, firing, and positions. General Administrative material includes meeting notices, correspondence, and other administrative items. DC 1707 Staff Representative files contain copies of outgoing staff representative correspondence and memoranda involving administrative issues, including bargaining, grievances, and meetings. Affiliated locals are listed in parenthesis when known.

Series IV: Officers and Staff-Administrative Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: One file, which includes mostly correspondence between Local 1707 officers (especially Benjamin Bially, Executive Director, 1963-1968) and AFSCME (including AFSCME President Jerry Wurf) over union procedural matters and organizing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Raglan George, Jr. was elected Executive Director of 1707 in 2002. Previous roles within the Council included director of Local 95 (Head Start) and Local 205 (Day Care Employees). Material in this subseries (approximately three boxes of records) generally relates to the administration and concerns of these locals and predates George's tenure as Executive Director.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a small amount of material from Josephine LeBeau, DC 1707 Executive Director from 1994 to 2002. Previous roles within the Council included Staff Representative and Director of Local 389. LeBeau was also involved with the Coalition of Labor Union Women (CLUW).

scopecontent.p: McEnroe served as Executive Director of DC 1707 from 1984 to 1994. Files in this subseries pertain to organizing, conferences, and administrative activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Powell serves as Local 95 President (circa 1990s-present) and as DC 1707 Treasurer (circa 1999-present). Much of the material in this small subseries pertains to Local 95.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Stokely served as President of DC 1707 (circa 2002-2004) and as Local 215 President. Much of the material in this subseries relates to Local 215 and its agencies, especially the New York Association for New Americans (NYANA), where Stokely was a shop steward. Items also document Stokely's activity or general interests in labor, politics and political protests.

Series V: Publications and Publicity Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Files contain research notes for and drafts of articles, presumably for publication in DC 1707 Voice or Council newsletters. Subjects include DC 1707's agencies, politics, issues of interest to Council members, and profiles of members. Also included are drafts of columns written by DC 1707 and AFSCME officers. Also included in this series are 199 floppy disks, which appear to contain articles, drafts, photos and graphics for DC 1707 publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: 13 reels of 16 mm microfilm containing DC 170 contracts from 1950-1990, clippings, arbitration awards, grievances, day care pension plans, YWCA national board records, victims information bureau records, JCC delegate assembly records 1974-1991, executive board and joint city council minutes 1963 and 1966, JNF arbitrations, and child development center records.

daodesc.p: District Council 1707 Wordpress Archived Website: May 2013-June 2017
District Council 1707 Calendar Archived Website: August 2014-October 2017

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: District Council 1707 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) is the only council within AFSCME that is chartered exclusively to represent private, nonprofit employees. From 2007-2013 the website contained information and news from the locals that made up the council--Local 95, Local 107, Local 205, Local 215, Local 253, Local 389, and retirees chapter. It also included news, issues of the Voice Notes, committee information for the political action committee, the Latino committee, Women's committee, and Coalition of Black Trade Unionists, as well as class and workshop details for steward and organizing training and membership benefits. In 2013, the website underwent a redesign to a blog format. The website mostly consisted of news and press releases from the Council, president and executive director addresses to membership, photo galleries, local and committee overviews, and information on classes and workshops. In 2015, the website was redesigned again and the captures up until 2017 are mostly not navigable, only news blurbs, headlines, and calendar are available. The last redesign occured in 2018. The website contained news, class and workshop registrations, political action meetings, photo galleries, employment opportunities, board members, and a calendar. News covered includes negotiation updates, marches and rallies, convertion news, obituaries, and leadership updates.In late 2019, DC 1707 merged with DC 37. The website ceased to exist circa 2020-2021.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Crawl was limited to domains and subdomains of https://www.dc1707.net/ in order to remain within the collection scope and data constraints.
